body:
I think this would be a very nice feature. :+1: from me.

AFAIK tracemalloc has a large memory overhead so enabling it by default is not an option, and neither is option 3 really.

Can the logic be something like this?

```py
if warning_message.source is not None:
    # If tracemalloc is active, and has captured the object's allocation, show where it was allocated.
    tb = tracemalloc.get_object_traceback(warning_message.source)
    if tb is not None:
        msg += "\nObject allocated at (most recent call first):\n" + (nice tb formatting here)
    else:
        Suggestion to enable tracemalloc (if it's not enabled), or increase the number of frames (if it is enabled)
        Is it helpful at all to do anything with `warning_message.source` here (like show its repr),
        or assume it's already covered by the warning message itself?
``` 

as for what to write in the suggestion, option 1 `pytest` -> `python -X tracemalloc=20 -m pytest` seems a bit awkward. An alternative is to suggest `PYTHONTRACEMALLOC=20 pytest`. Or we can just add the command line argument (option 2). Not sure which is better. Maybe avoid the cmdline argument at first, and only add if if people encounter difficulties without it.
Sounds good to me too, thanks folks!

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.title: Investigate leaking resources in tests

repository.name: neon
repository.description: Neon: Serverless Postgres. We separated storage and compute to offer autoscaling, code-like database branching, and scale to zero.

issue.body:
In [this](https://github.com/neondatabase/neon/pull/2210) PR I tried to enable pytest to treat warnings as errors and it turns out we have significant amount of resource warnings related to resources (most commonly sockets) which are not closed properly

@bayandin pointed out that pytest 7.1 introduces a way to trace this warnings to a point where resource was allocated. See: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/9644 Because otherwise you have to guess what is causing the warning
